item.title: MAT3RIAL IS
item.dc:creator: MAT3RIALadmin
item.content:encoded:
[efsrow] [efscolumn lg="4" md="6" smoff="0" mdoff="0" lgoff="0" ] [/efscolumn] [efscolumn lg="8" md="6" smoff="0" mdoff="0" lgoff="0" ]

Corina MacDonald is an information specialist and developer. She completed a Masters degree in Library and Information Studies in 2008 at McGill University, with a specialization in knowledge management. Her professional interests include the role of open content, technologies and standards in community and capacity building, electronic publishing and digital heritage. She worked as a heritage information analyst at the Canadian Heritage Information Network from 2008 to 2010 before beginning work as an independent consultant for digital cultural projects. She is currently the Project Manager for the e-artexte repository for visual arts publishing, and a freelance webmaster and trainer.

[/efscolumn] [/efsrow]
  [efsrow] [efscolumn lg="8" md="6" smoff="0" mdoff="0" lgoff="0" ]

Jacqueline Wallace draws from her extensive experience in growing and managing a series of creative industry startups to bring MAT3RIAL clients effective strategy and design solutions. She is a former co-founder of Veer Inc. (veer.com), an award-winning visual media and design company, where she worked as VP, International to establish the company's Berlin and London headquarters and a distribution channel of over 250 partners worldwide. She is also a founding partner of the cheekily named All Beef Media, a boutique social media marketing and analytics company run by four women. Wallace holds a PhD in Communication from Concordia University. Her research examined women, entrepreneurship and micro-economies of craft in the digital era. She is also one of the founding board members of the Fembot Collective, a scholarly collaboration promoting research on gender, media, and technology.

[/efscolumn] [efscolumn lg="4" md="6" smoff="0" mdoff="0" lgoff="0" ] [/efscolumn] [/efsrow]
  [efsrow] [efscolumn lg="4" md="6" smoff="0" mdoff="0" lgoff="0" ] [/efscolumn] [efscolumn lg="8" md="6" smoff="0" mdoff="0" lgoff="0" ]

Mél Hogan lives and works in Chicago. She is an Assistant Professor of Communication at IIT, where she teaches Document Design. She recently completed a Postdoctoral Fellowship in Digital Curation at the University of Colorado – Boulder. She has a background in Graphic Design (Algonquin College 2001), a Graduate Production Diploma, a Masters in Media Studies, and a Research Creation PhD in Communication Studies, all from Concordia University, in Montréal. She is a member of various archive-related research teams and publishes and presents widely at conferences in Canada, the US, and beyond. She is also the Art Director of nomorepotlucks.org, a queer feminist journal of arts and politics. For mat3rial.com, she explores tools for DIY publishing and design, and is interested in developing a platform for easy web to print interoperability.

[/efscolumn] [/efsrow]
  [efsrow] [efscolumn lg="8" md="6" smoff="0" mdoff="0" lgoff="0" ]

Antonia Hernández is a graphic designer and visual artist, currently pursuing a PhD in Communication at Concordia University, Montréal. Mixing media practice and theoretical research, her interests involve the domestic side of digital networks, interfaces and pornography. She works independently for different academic labs, consulting and providing public and visual output to diverse types of research.

[/efscolumn] [efscolumn lg="4" md="6" smoff="0" mdoff="0" lgoff="0" ] [/efscolumn] [/efsrow]

[/av_textblock] [av_hr class='invisible' height='100' shadow='no-shadow' position='center'] [/av_one_full] [/av_section] [av_section color='main_color' custom_bg='' src='http://dev.mat3rial.com/mat3rial2014/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/bg_slide02.jpg' attachment='62' attachment_size='full' attach='parallax' position='top left' repeat='no-repeat' video='' video_ratio='16:9' min_height='' padding='default' shadow='no-shadow' id=''] [av_one_full first] [av_textblock ] [su_row][su_column size="1/3"]

CURATING DATA

  [/su_column][su_column size="2/3"]Researchers need to effectively manage the data generated by their projects. We provide sustainable solutions to research teams for the management, presentation and archiving of project data, media content and publications. [/su_column] [/su_row] [/av_textblock] [av_hr class='invisible' height='100' shadow='no-shadow' position='center'] [/av_one_full] [/av_section] [av_section color='main_color' custom_bg='' src='http://dev.mat3rial.com/mat3rial2014/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/background_BLUE.png' attachment='115' attachment_size='full' attach='parallax' position='top left' repeat='no-repeat' video='' video_ratio='16:9' min_height='' padding='default' shadow='no-shadow' id=''] [av_one_full first] [av_textblock ] [su_row][su_column size="1/3"]

DESIGN FOR INFORMATION

  [/su_column][su_column size="2/3"]Design is an essential part of any research output. We develop meaningful custom interfaces and designs appropriate to specific information needs and audiences. [/su_column] [/su_row] [/av_textblock] [av_hr class='invisible' height='100' shadow='no-shadow' position='center'] [/av_one_full] [/av_section] [av_section color='main_color' custom_bg='' src='http://dev.mat3rial.com/mat3rial2014/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/background_GREY.png' attachment='117' attachment_size='full' attach='parallax' position='top left' repeat='no-repeat' video='' video_ratio='16:9' min_height='' padding='default' shadow='no-shadow' id=''] [av_one_full first] [av_textblock ] [su_row][su_column size="1/3"]

PUBLISHING ONLINE

  [/su_column][su_column size="2/3"]Research results need to be effectively communicated to a variety of audiences. We ensure that your publications, media and collections are visible, searchable and accessible in the online environment. item.title: futuristic vision, expanded cinema and the archive
item.dc:creator: MAT3RIALadmin
item.content:encoded:
For the past few weeks, MAT3RIAL's been working on the visual identity for a research project that intersects cinema and archives. Specifically, this team of scholars, archivists, and filmmakers explores Expo 67's most ingenious screen experiments. They write:
The Canadian Expo 67 films attracted worldwide attention and enormous audiences, and our project focuses on fundamental research and contextualization of some of the most important films to have disappeared from the Canadian film canon. While parts of the Expo films were reproduced in conventional formats and early versions of IMAX, the possibility of seeing the entire works in anything like their original context ended with the demolition of the Expo pavilions in which they were shown. The consequence has been a decline in awareness to the point where recent studies of Canadian cinema make little or no mention of them. These multi-screen productions challenged both the cinema production technology of the day, modes of screening, audience reception, as well as the received wisdom as to what cinema was or could be.
MAT3RIAL is preparing the project logo and online presence for the project. The visual identity concepts work off of two main ideas: “An archive of a cinema expanded beyond the frame”  (expanded cinema, multi-screen, archive) and "A creative, multiple gaze" (total environments, futuristic vision, expanded cinema). The website will focus on the creative processes of the 60’s filmmakers and provide a documentary-style portal that forefronts the visual components of the archive. It will also serve as both a repository that brings together diverse and possibly crowdsourced contents (fan and institutional) and a space for audio programs for exhibitions, starting with a Polar Life recreation in October 2014 at La Cinémathèque québécoise. Project branding and website to be launched August 2014...

item.title: old logos, copyright and trademarks
item.dc:creator: MAT3RIALadmin
item.content:encoded:
As we are working with contents from Expo67, we're encountering questions of copyright and trademark that are necessary to flesh out in order to provide our client a logo that is hassle free in terms of infringement. What we've discovered is that the logo for Expo67 is in the public domain and the "Expo67" in Optima is under trademark. The public domain makes it possible for us to appropriate and to freely use the main concept and branding of the original Expo67 design. In terms of design, what's interesting is the following reasons for why it is considered public domain:
This image only consists of simple geometric shapes and/or text. It does not meet the threshold of originality needed for copyright protection, and is therefore in the public domain.
Arguably, simplicity should not undermine what a logo can communicate. Often simple shapes are the most powerful. That being said, the ability to share and 'remix' concepts is incredibly valuable to the creative process and speaks to the flow of ideas that should remain as open as possible. Trademark is trickier. Does it prevent us from using words that refer to the expo from 1967? If so, how can we work around it? What are the limitations? Since our logo works with a different font and refers to "cinema expo67" as a project title, we are simply nodding at the original context. Being limited in terms of the words we can use becomes a design obstacle.

item.title: MAT3RIAL IS
item.dc:creator: MAT3RIALadmin
item.content:encoded:
[efsrow] [efscolumn lg="4" md="6" smoff="0" mdoff="0" lgoff="0" ] [/efscolumn] [efscolumn lg="8" md="6" smoff="0" mdoff="0" lgoff="0" ]

Corina MacDonald is an information specialist and developer. She completed a Masters degree in Library and Information Studies in 2008 at McGill University, with a specialization in knowledge management. Her professional interests include the role of open content, technologies and standards in community and capacity building, electronic publishing and digital heritage. She worked as a heritage information analyst at the Canadian Heritage Information Network from 2008 to 2010 before beginning work as an independent consultant for digital cultural projects. She is currently the Project Manager for the e-artexte repository for visual arts publishing, and a freelance webmaster and trainer.

[/efscolumn] [/efsrow]
  [efsrow] [efscolumn lg="8" md="6" smoff="0" mdoff="0" lgoff="0" ]

Jacqueline Wallace draws from her extensive experience in growing and managing a series of creative industry startups to bring MAT3RIAL clients effective strategy and design solutions. She is a former co-founder of Veer Inc. (veer.com), an award-winning visual media and design company, where she worked as VP, International to establish the company's Berlin and London headquarters and a distribution channel of over 250 partners worldwide. She is also a founding partner of the cheekily named All Beef Media, a boutique social media marketing and analytics company run by four women. Wallace holds a PhD in Communication from Concordia University. Her research examined women, entrepreneurship and micro-economies of craft in the digital era. She is also one of the founding board members of the Fembot Collective, a scholarly collaboration promoting research on gender, media, and technology.

[/efscolumn] [efscolumn lg="4" md="6" smoff="0" mdoff="0" lgoff="0" ] [/efscolumn] [/efsrow]
  [efsrow] [efscolumn lg="4" md="6" smoff="0" mdoff="0" lgoff="0" ] [/efscolumn] [efscolumn lg="8" md="6" smoff="0" mdoff="0" lgoff="0" ]

Mél Hogan lives and works in Chicago. She is an Assistant Professor of Communication at IIT, where she teaches Document Design. She recently completed a Postdoctoral Fellowship in Digital Curation at the University of Colorado – Boulder. She has a background in Graphic Design (Algonquin College 2001), a Graduate Production Diploma, a Masters in Media Studies, and a Research Creation PhD in Communication Studies, all from Concordia University, in Montréal. She is a member of various archive-related research teams and publishes and presents widely at conferences in Canada, the US, and beyond. She is also the Art Director of nomorepotlucks.org, a queer feminist journal of arts and politics. For mat3rial.com, she explores tools for DIY publishing and design, and is interested in developing a platform for easy web to print interoperability.

[/efscolumn] [/efsrow]
  [efsrow] [efscolumn lg="8" md="6" smoff="0" mdoff="0" lgoff="0" ]

Antonia Hernandez is a graphic and web designer. She finished a Masters degree in Media Studies at Concordia University, Montreal. Mixing media practice and theoretical research, her interests involve the domestic side of digital networks, interfaces and alternative education. She works independently for different academic labs, consulting and providing public and visual output to diverse types of research.

[/efscolumn] [efscolumn lg="4" md="6" smoff="0" mdoff="0" lgoff="0" ] [/efscolumn] [/efsrow]

item.title: “Everyone has their outlet, and this is mine.” An Interview with Graphic Designer Noor Abdelrahim – by Saja Hamayel
item.dc:creator: mel
item.content:encoded:
My professor (Mél Hogan) asked us to interview a Graphic Designer as part of our Information Structure and Retrieval class (at IIT). Being the only woman and Muslim in the class, I decided this was a perfect opportunity to have my story was told as well. A friend directed me to one of the few female Muslims in our community who work as a Graphic Designer. I contacted Noor Abdelrahim and was soon able to visit her at her workspace, MorningStar Inc., a Financial Investment Company in downtown Chicago. We sat down one Tuesday afternoon in one of the many open-space glass rooms in MorningStar where I chronicled our conversation.   Saja Hamayel: When did you decide to be a graphic designer? Noor Abdelrahim: I guess, to give you some background: in high school, I did a lot of photography. I took some photo classes in high school. I was really into analog photography, so film, working in a dark room, actually manually printing that stuff. I was really into films. My sisters and I would shoot ourselves doing things and make mini movies and things like that and I would edit them. I love to edit it. I taught myself how to use Adobe Premiere. So that's where I was at. Didn't know what design was, never heard of it. So I was sitting there frustrated trying to think of what I wanted to do. I'm like, should I do photography? I knew I wanted to do something in the arts. I hated math, I hated science. I don't hate it;  I love astronomy and things like that but I just knew I couldn't do it.
"Wait, there's a job for what I already do?" - Noor Abdelrahim
So I applied as undeclared which was a big mistake because I lost a year for that but everything happens for a reason. I applied as undeclared but during that time, I figured it out. Someone said, "Have you ever heard of graphic design? I think that would be perfect for you.” And I started researching it. After I read about it I was like, "Wait, there's a job for what I already do?"  Because I already loved making posters, I liked organizing things like that. So I already did that without really knowing what design was. So I was like, wow, this is perfect. So that's when I decided, like yeah, this is it. And once I actually started with the classes I knew for sure; I do like this. This is what I have to do. This is what I'm meant to do! I went to UIC;  I stayed for 5 years. The program, the way it works, it takes four years once you actually start the program and since I applied as undeclared I was in a different college and I couldn't take design classes so I had to wait. Took Gen-Eds. Long story short, I started sophomore year with design. I like the design at UIC. It's similar to IIT [Institute of Design] and Basel and Yale. There are some other schools like Columbia or DePaul. Their approach to design is just to teach people how to create portfolio pieces versus learning a process and then taking that stuff that you learned and applying it to like whatever.  So that's how UIC Design sort of was. The end of my sophomore year, I was taking a class with Professor Philip Burton; it was a typography class. He works here and he always told us things about MorningStar. He'll just bring it up and talk about it all the time. Like all the time! And one day professors were sending out internship opportunities here at MorningStar. So my whole class applied since we all went to UIC and since the professor knew us they took us straight to the interview process which was nice. But once we got there, we were sort of fighting each other for these internship jobs. So we went in and interviewed and I got an internship here and I was like, Cool, now, I have an internship, which is good when it comes to design and things like that. So, that's how I got here and then I stayed here for two years as an intern. I graduated recently in May 2015, so I've only been working full-time since September.   SH: So, are you saying that graphic design is a competitive job? NA: Oh, it's very competitive. Yes. You're literally going to be competing with your classmates, with everybody in the city for these jobs because, I don't wanna say that there aren't that many positions for design, but it just seems like there aren't. There are so many smaller studios and they only have a few people and it's really hard  to get in somewhere. Especially when it comes to this field, because it's not only based on what your test scores are like, or what your GPA is like. Some places, they look at personality. They look at your work, obviously. So it's like a culture, depending on whatever place you get into, you kind of have to fit, and if you don't...   SH: ...you're out? NA: Exactly. See, in terms of how it applies to me as a Muslim - like when I was applying, there's some places, for me...there were some people in my class who took the approach of - I'm just gonna apply to every single place and hopefully, I get something. But, for me, I couldn't do that. Even though I knew it was hard to find a place, I didn't want to apply to places that I didn't really care about and then have to stay there. I didn't want to be too picky obviously, because I just graduated, but I wanted to find a place where I liked the work that they do and the environment was good. So there were some places like smaller studio places, where I love the work that they do, but I felt I wouldn't be able to fit in with the people and their lifestyle. So, this one studio; it was a very nice studio and I went and visited it and everything and they were just like drinking as they worked, and I just didn't see it working. Even though I loved their work, it just wouldn't work with how I live. So, that's why I like MorningStar, a slightly bigger place. It's more of a 9-5 job. You have coworkers, but it's not like, Oh we have to hang out like all the time because we're only like three people and we're literally always working together. I feel like I found that balance with design even though the stuff we're designing is financial stuff, it's not the most exciting stuff in the world. It's not the stuff we worked on in school, but I still felt like I could do this and do things outside of it too. And I also think that if I do the type of work that I love all the time, for work, like, if it was my job? I feel like I would eventually hate it just because it was my job.   SH: Are your parents supportive of you being a female Muslim designer? NA: My dad maybe not as crazy about it as my mom, but they both always want to help out with my projects. One of my projects in school was to create three-dimensional letters. And then from there, we had to photograph them and then design a book with them. It was the most insane class ever. But one of the things I wanted to do – I wanted to make them out of branches and things, so we would go into the woods. And they would go in and cut things down for me. They helped out a lot! And they’re always showing people my stuff. They’re always talking about me. They’re so proud….too proud. It always frustrates me when I hear situations where – I can’t count how many times other Muslim girls have come up to me and ask me what I do. I tell them design and they say, “That’s what I really wanted to do!” So I ask them: Oh, are you doing it? They say: No, I’m a doctor now. It frustrates me so much! I understand, but it frustrates me, because you’re the one who’s gonna be doing this and not your parents. So when parents force their kids to do things? It’s just something that I really care about. This is a general problem, where people’s parents say: No, you can’t do this, you have to do this. And they do that and listen to their parents and they hate it. I’m sure it’s very miserable. I could never do it; I could never.   SH: Do you think your career choice is good for Muslim women? And why? NA: Yes, because there aren’t that many in the field. People keep complaining, and it’s usually the older generation. They’ll say: Look at all these people in film talking about Muslims and whatnot and all these people creating these advertisements and things about Muslims… Well, if there were more Muslims in the field, then we wouldn’t be having this issue. But they’re not! They’re all doctors. And it’s great, doctors are awesome, but we have plenty of doctors. We need more people in these fields. And they’re more important than people think. They can actually make a difference. We can actually make a difference with these causes that you actually care about [older generation complainers] that have to do with Muslims through design!   SH: Yeah. A lot of Muslim organizations have really bad design and it’s so sad because the first that you see when you see an organization is the design like the logo and the fliers. NA: Exactly! People don’t understand how important this is. Small things like typos make a big difference; they honestly do. Bad design makes the organization seem unprofessional.   SH: I agree. So what do you do here at MorningStar? NA: I'm a designer in the Design Department here. At MorningStar, design is sort of split into two big sections. We have the Marketing Designers and we have the Product Designers. The Marketing Designers would create promotional materials, emails, posters, any books, editorial things. The Product Designers are sort of broken up; within product design, we have different products - digital products that MorningStar has. One team is the mobile team so they work on all the mobile applications. I used to be on that team; I started out on that team as an intern. While I was on that team, we would design the interface for all the apps. Right now, though, I'm on a different project for a different software that we have and it's called Morningstar Direct. It's more for institutional clients. So people who actually work on this stuff and have to do intense research. So it's a very complex program. But within that, I work on the Research part of it, which is the articles and things like that.   SH: You do things outside of MorningStar, right? NA: I do. I definitely do. Do you want me to start listing things I do?   SH: List everything. NA: Everything? I do a lot of things that I don't get to do at work just for fun because I like to do it and to help people out. My focus with the stuff I do outside are to focus on things for Muslims and Islam because I know that design is one of the things that is the last thing that they think about and is one of the biggest things that they need. So I like to volunteer my time there. So I do, if you've heard of Seeking Shade at Mosque Foundation?   SH: Yeah! NA: So I work on all the [fliers]...   SH: Oh! They're so nice! NA: You like them?   SH: Yeah! NA: I make those. Wow! I'm glad you've actually noticed. Because I'm always like, I wonder what people think about these…   SH: I really like them. I like the whole concept of them. It's really pretty. NA: Awesome, awesome. I came up with a structure for it and then just stuck with that just so it could be consistent every time and just change it based on the theme. So Seeking Shade fliers. What else do I do? I help out AMP [American Muslims for Palestine] with the logo right now. Hopefully I can help out with more stuff later too. And I also do a lot of stuff for UIC - [University of Illinois in Chicago]. That’s where I went for school - for their MSA [Muslim Student Association] mostly because my sister is currently in the MSA right now. They have this publication called Al-Bayyan and so this year, I redesigned their front covers to have another consistent thing and because their old one was sort of out of date. It wasn't that great so we redesigned that and I helped them come up with a template for the inside so that they could do that on their own for each issue. So I do a lot of stuff for them.   Al-Bayyan design before:   After:   SH: Can you walk me through your design process, from getting an idea or assignment, to getting the final product? NA: Obviously, I work on a big project with multiple people, it's not just me working on it. We have these different squads. So for me, it's one Visual Designer, one UX [User Experience] Designer, and then we have a Business Analyst, a Product Manager, a couple Front-End Developers, a couple Back-End Developers. And we're all working as a team on this project. So what usually happens is Product will come to us and be like - so let me apply it to something we're working on now - they'll come and they'll say, users want a bookmarks page, or they wanna be able to bookmark articles that they want to read later or that they liked, so they'll tell us the requirements. So once we get the requirements, me and the UX Designers sort of work together...   SH: What's the UX? NA: UX Design is the experience and the interaction part of the design. And there's the Visual, which is what I do, which is exactly the color of things, the size of things, how things actually look. But they focus on the transition, the layout of things.   SH: How do you separate the visual and the UX? NA: We kind of don't. We kind of work together. I'll give feedback on UX, they kinda give feedback on me a little, but like, you need the eye for Visual Design. But UX is not about how it looks, it's more about how it behaves, how the user would behave with it. So they'll figure out like what happens - how do you remove a bookmarked page from the bookmarks page? They'll be like, "Oh, you can hover over the row and maybe an icon comes up and then you click on that and it disappears right away. Or we can have another row that has the bookmarked icon and if they click on that ..."   SH: So it's like the interaction part? NA: Right. That's what they figure out. And that stuff traditionally comes first before Visual even touches anything. They'll create wireframes; they're not pretty or anything, they just quickly show the structure of what they're thinking. Sometimes UX Designers will ask me to come and brainstorm with them to come up with ideas; help them out from a visual perspective. Then they'll create the wireframes, we'll talk to the Product Team, see if they like it. We'll talk to other designers in the company. We have this Visual Standards meeting where everyone shares designs from their different products and gets more feedback. So once everyone is like, ok, this is good, then it comes to me and I work on it and then the same process [of feedback]. So, my process? Once I get a wireframe, I look at it and I start with just laying everything out. I basically create all the objects that I need just so I have them there and I lay them out similar to how the UX had them because they already decided on where everything goes. Also, luckily, for most things, we already have standards for them so I basically just have to figure out how to put it together using those standards. It's usually already kind of half-way figured out. There are other things that are like really new and no one's ever done it before and that's when you have to try different things. I usually open up - I have an Illustrator file and I create artboard after artboard, trying, tweaking just a small thing. I create a new artboard, tweak it a little bit and I just show it to people and we talk about it.   SH: So there's a lot of feedback and going through a lot of people? NA: Yes, yes. At work! It's very different outside of work. Usually, I'm the only one working on the project, obviously. So if I'm creating a poster or, the Seeking Shade flier, Banan [person in charge of Seeking Shade] - will send me an email saying this what our theme is gonna be for the next issue,  I need this on there, I need that on there, this is the time, whatever. I get all that information and since I already created a template, it's easy; I'll just change all the dates and everything. But then when I think about the theme, I really start to think about it. And it's usually just me in my head and I'm like - So if the theme is the Eloquence of Arabic in the Qur'an? That one was a hard one. Should I just show Qur'an? I don't know. I start thinking about what it means. Like sometimes, I get really deep into it conceptually. Like I mentioned to you, I like the conceptual part of design. My whole thesis was about how design can be art and people can express themselves through design. It can be functional; obviously it's functional, but I also think it could be art too. In school, we always debated this.   SH: Why wouldn't it be art? NA: Some professors would be like, “No, if you want to be an artist, you're in the wrong field; leave.” I felt very strongly about it so I made my whole thesis about it. For me, how I think about it, it's just the way that I express myself.   SH: What kind of softwares do you use and did you choose these? NA: Well, I use a lot of the Adobe Software. It's the best thing that's available and I mean, workwise, that's what we have to use. That's what they buy for us. So Ilustrator is what I usually use to create the stuff. If I need to tweak an image or something, I'll use Photoshop sometimes. I used to use InDesign to create specs and things, but now I do that in Illustrator.   SH: Oh! Really? Isn't it easier in InDesign? NA: InDesign is kind of annoying. Actually, technically, it might seem like it is [easier]. Illustrator is kind of weird. When you first look at it, you're like, “What is going on?” But when you get used to it, you'll like it better. You can do pixels, but they're still like vector graphics. Where in InDesign, you can't really do things by the pixel, so nothing is ever perfect and it's annoying. You should stick to InDesign when you're working on layouts of things, like posters. I mean, sometimes I'll do posters on InDesign. Yeah, text and things like that. What else do I use? After Effects. They [MorningStar] figured out that I knew how to use After Effects so they said,  "Oh, can you make these videos?" I made technical stuff for them. When I was on the Mobile Team and we came out with a new thing for the app, they'll ask, “Can you make a video showing you can click on this and this is what happens and you can click on that..." So I did that in After Effects.   SH: So that's like animated? NA: Yes. Motion graphics. So it's like a combination of Premiere and Flash. You can take images and move them around.   SH: So you worked on those in college? NA: In college, yes. We were required to get all of this [Adobe Software] and they taught us everything. When you first start out, it's mostly technical classes and then once you actually learn the software, you create some things on there. Junior year and senior year is where you use what you learned: design principles and technical skills to create more conceptual work that you are coming up with all on your own.   SH: Do you use any grids? Do you use grids religiously? NA: Yes. Yes. I mean, I don't let them conquer my decisions. First of all, anyone who's a designer would know this; a trained designer would know:  you start out with a grid, you put everything on a grid and then you try to break the grid.   SH: Why would you break the grid? NA: Because that's how you come up with something very crazy and interesting.   SH: So you use grids outside of work too? NA: Yes. Those are kind of different.   SH: Do you use the columns and the rows or...? NA: I use the baseline grid; I love the baseline grid.   SH: How long would you say a project takes? So let's say, for the Seeking Shade one? The first time you ever made it? Coming up with the template...? NA: That took a couple weeks, I would say. It depends on how much time you give it. Like it could take a month if you only work on it a few hours a week, but I had work to deal with and school. I was still in school during that time so it took a little while. But once I figured that out, it took like 3 days max, to finish a project. Creating a logo takes a long time.   SH: Yeah, for some reason, everyone says logos are very difficult? NA: They're so hard!   SH: Why? NA: Because trying to come up with something that is clever, yet simple, also on a grid? It's  just really hard to create something new, I guess.   SH: And timeless. NA: And timeless. And not like everything else that you see; without copying anything else. It's just really really hard. Logos take forever. Those are the hardest. Posters, usually not that long. The more you've done this before, the quicker it becomes. You can skip sort of those beginning stages and go through them really quickly because you've done it so many times. How you set up something is always the same in the beginning. Then once you got that down...   SH: You break the grid? NA: Yes, you start breaking the grid.   SH: So how do you choose your color schemes? NA: Usually, I try to think of, "What do the colors mean? How do they go with the theme?" So if it's something very dark, I try to use darker colors. If I have images as inspiration for it, I'll try to get a color from the image, like I'll color pick it. And then I'll take that color and I'll go into Adobe Kuler, then I can start creating schemes. So I'll start out with a color I like, from an image; I'll put it in here [Adobe Kuler] and then from there I'll be like, “Do I want it to be monochromatic? Do i want to see some complimentary colors to this color?” I'll start with one color, and then I'll come in here and try the different options, mess around in here and try them out and see if they work or not. “Sometimes I feel like color is not even necessary if something is beautiful on its own.” - Noor Abdelrahim   SH: I've noticed that most of your works are black and white. Why do you choose those colors? A lot of it is black white and then one color. NA: Then like a color, right? I always start...when I start designing something, I don't even think about color. I appreciate form and things like that so...   SH: You add color later? NA: Sometimes I feel like color is not even necessary if something is beautiful on its own. I only add color when I feel it's absolutely necessary. I'm not one of those people that will put color everywhere. I'll try not to use that much color. I'll choose one or two…   SH: Most of your stuff is very conceptual, it's not... NA: It's more based on, yeah, the idea behind it.   SH: It's like abstract. NA: Yeah, that's a good way to describe it.   SH: What non-design skills do you find most essential to master in order to be a successful graphic designer? NA: I don't know if things are essential.   Well, brainstorming, working with other people. If you're working on a bigger project, working with other people, learning how to listen. If you have clients, learning how to listen to them. And, one of the hardest things for designers is compromise. Sometimes, you have to compromise. You wanna do something a certain way, but the person you're doing it for wants something else. So it's just, that's a good skill to have because it's hard. And taking criticism. Constructive criticism, hopefully! It’s like your work - it's your child, you made this, you have to learn how to let go sometimes. You made something and you love it, but sometimes that thing that you made and love so much isn't what gets chosen or isn’t what moves forward. In terms of technical skills, it helps when you know some photography, or know how to draw. It's not necessary, but it helps.   SH: Do you know how to draw? NA:  I know how to draw, but, when it comes to dimension, I just don’t have that – the realism. The stuff I draw is just flat. That’s just my style and aesthetic, I think. Usually, my stuff is very flat.   SH: Where do you get your inspiration from? People? Art Movements? Nature? NA: That's a good one, uhmm...Situations.   SH: Situations? NA: Yeah. Things that are happening to me: usually things that frustrate me, things that are annoying. That's usually when I'm like, “I need to make a piece on this.” Like, you know? Politics, anything that happens. There's a lot going on with Muslims, nowadays. That's where I get most of my...like, that's what fuels all of this. Where I'm like, “I have to make something to tell people about this or to get people to wonder about this. So what's better than like making a poster about it or like a little video piece or something?” That's usually what happens; people assuming things and me being like, “No, this how it's really like.” When something frustrates me, I have to...I start making something for it. This is the way that I express...that's how I react to things. I'll be like, “Oh, I need to make a video about it or I need to make a poster about it and post it or send it to people, or print it out and put it places.” That's how I react to situations. Everyone reacts, but that's how I react.   SH: Yeah, I write. NA: You write? See? Everyone has their outlet, and this is mine.   SH: What does good design mean to you and how do you know if someone uses design well? Technically? Aesthetically? Both? NA: It's designed well, I would say, if the person or the people that you meant to design it for receive it and think about it the same way that you thought about it.   SH: If the message is clear. NA: Exactly, if the message is clear, you know you did your job. If the message you wanted to portray is...if they got that by looking at it, then you did a good job, right? It was successful. Aesthetically? Honestly, everyone has different...there's so many different styles. There are really good designers and I don't like their style. That doesn't mean it's not good or not successful, I just don't like it. So, I would say aesthetically, I can tell if someone wasn't a trained designer. I can tell if things aren't using a grid, if they're using too many typefaces, too many font sizes, if things are all over the place. Sometimes people do it intentionally though, but I can tell because everything starts out on a grid and they broke it. I can tell that by looking at something because I'm a designer. A random person probably wouldn't be able to. I can tell that they actually know what they're doing, even when they're breaking grids and doing crazy things, there's still structure to it. There's still something there that's holding it together. There's still something there that makes it work. That's why it frustrates me when people think that just because anyone can teach themselves Adobe. You can watch videos and you can learn how to do stuff, but you have to also teach yourself design and train your eye to look at things that way and when you don't, you can tell. One thing that people don't understand, or that they don't appreciate as much is how much time and how much effort it actually takes to design something. They'll think like, “Oh a poster? That should take you, like an hour, like I can do this.” That's what frustrates me. Sometimes, you'll work with people and they're like, “Why is it taking you so long? I could've done that.” It's harder than you think and people don't get that sometimes.
“Never stare at a blank artboard ever. Never. It's death.” - Noor Abdelrahim
  SH: I feel like the scariest thing is when you just see a blank sheet. NA: That's the scariest feeling in the world. Sometimes, I just have to put something on there just so it's not blank. That's why I start by just putting all the elements that I need so if someone tells me, “It needs to have this title, this date”, I'll at least...even if I haven't styled them, I'll just put them there and just start moving them around.  Never stare at a blank artboard ever. Never. It's death.   SH: Have you ever turned down work or a project based on the ethos of the client? NA: No, I’ve turned down because of time.  A few times. Even though, usually, I say yes.  There was this one project that my professor asked me to be part of and I said, I have all this homework to do and I’m working on all this other stuff. As much as I wanted to do it, I couldn’t do it. And my professor just responds: it takes a really strong designer to turn down a project. And I’m just like…   SH: I’m very strong! NA: Exactly! But, on a serious note,  if there’s a place where the type of work that they do, I don’t believe in or something like that, I obviously wouldn’t wanna…or if they support a certain thing that I don’t support, why would I want to help them? So I would turn it down, but I haven’t encountered that situation before. I mean I just graduated so, my career is still ahead of me. I’m sure that will happen at some point.   SH: Before you start designing, do you sketch out your ideas? NA: Sometimes. Sometimes, I’ll quickly sketch it just because it’s faster. But other times I’ll just be in Illustrator and I’ll quickly try things out. I’ll draw it in Illustrator sometimes, but if I’m not in Illustrator, I’ll imagine it in my head and quickly sketch it out.   SH: So you don’t usually do a lot of sketching, you just do a lot on the computer. NA: I do a lot on the computer. Mostly on the computer, yeah. I mean, sketching is something that was part of our process during school. Usually they would force us to do it. In the beginning, our first few classes, they would force us to do these stages. They’re like: you have to make at least this many sketches and then you have to take photographs.   SH: What’s your favorite part in designing something, in the whole design process? NA: The end result. Just seeing it in action. Like seeing the Seeking Shade flier up at Jumaah [Friday Prayer at the Mosque] or like just seeing your work and seeing other people? You just think: wow, that actually turned out pretty nice and all of those hours were worth it!   SH: And when you design something, you see it differently than other people see it because you see all the flaws? NA: Yes. I’ll think: Oh God, I should’ve kerned that some more or if only I moved it over a few pixels! But then I’ll show it to my mom – my mom likes everything, though, regardless. Maybe it’s just because shes my mom? But she’ll always be like: “Oh my God! So cute! I love it!” And she’ll show her coworkers. It’s nice though. My parents have always been supportive.   SH: That’s awesome! I think that’s all the questions we have. Thank you so much for having me!   NA: Thank you for interviewing me! Noor’s online portfolio: http://cargocollective.com/noorabdelrahim   Noor Abdelrahim + her workspace:

item.title: e-artexte
item.dc:creator: MAT3RIALadmin
item.content:encoded:
e-artexte is an open access digital repository  for visual arts publishing in Canada. It was officially launched on February 9, 2013. This expansion of Artexte’s service into the digital realm offers an opportunity for museums, galleries, artist-run centres and other publishers/authors in the visual arts community to create and distribute documentation in digital format. Corina MacDonald has been the e-artexte Project Manager since January 2011 and is currently developing training materials for digital publishing and open access for visual arts organizations. Antonia Hernandez developed the  design elements of the repository website based on design and branding guidelines produced by studio feed.

[su_button url="http://e-artexte.ca/" target="blank" style="flat" center="yes" radius="0" icon="icon: external-link-sign"]see this website[/su_button]

item.title: ADD
item.dc:creator: MAT3RIALadmin
item.content:encoded: I bet any designer has a long history of rejections, and I don't mean (only) in romantic terms. This job was particularly sad because it started so well. I worked a lot and the feedback was amazing. Everything seemed to go over smooth wheels, and I was pretty satisfied with the results. But, here it comes the lesson, the client was a whole directory, and most of them were unaware of that love history. In brief, nowadays they have an abandoned flash website.

item.title: MemorySpace
item.dc:creator: MAT3RIALadmin
item.content:encoded: MemorySpace was an interactive exhibition showing the memories from older adults in a collaboration between the Mobile Media Lab and the Atwater Library. We made the website, including posters and postcards for this beautiful project. The better part was an email from one of the participants saying how happy he was seeing his memories on the website.

item.title: Going Public
item.dc:creator: MAT3RIALadmin
item.excerpt:encoded: Web repository of interviews of socially engaged practitioners involved in theatre, film, new media and history into conversation to explore the political, aesthetic and performative dimensions of Going Public in an era of multimedia authorship.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Going Public brings a range of socially engaged practitioners involved in theatre, film, new media and history into conversation to explore the political, aesthetic and performative dimensions of our work. What are the creative and ethical challenges we face? What are possibilities for community-university collaborations? What are our strategies when addressing sensitive issues like genocide, human rights abuses or gender discrimination? What are the tools and methods we use to get our work to diverse publics across multiple platforms? Practitioners from around the world reflect on the process, the art and the significance of Going Public in an era of multimedia authorship.

item.title: "The Archive as Dumpster" - a talk by Mél Hogan at IIT ID
item.dc:creator: mel
item.content:encoded: I was recently invited by Laura Forlano to give a talk at IIT's Institute of Design. My talk was on the concept of preservation and the interconnectedness of memory/history, privacy and the environment. In four exploratory theoretical gestures (appraise, dispose, hoard, and mediate), I proposes the “archive as dumpster” is a framework for returning to the physical conditions of memory that subverts traditional archival methodologies by insisting on the very material consequences of a culture inculcated in networked digital communications. I make the argument that by posing the archive as a mediatic question (Parikka), we can begin to account more seriously for the ways in which the perceived immateriality and weightlessness of our data have important humanistic, environmental, political, and ethical repercussions. Pitting the archive’s orderly ambitions against the dumpster’s stinking mess reveals a “call of things” (Bennett)—the slow and often distanced process of disposal and waste—to remind us who we are, in and over time, in and out of our bodies, and increasingly under the impression of a dematerialized engagement with our stuff and ourselves. [img from The Register]

item.title: Interview with graphic designer Jayme Spinks
item.dc:creator: mel
item.content:encoded: The following is an interview conducted with Interview with Jayme Spinks over the course of the last 6 months. This interview with Spinks starts off our regular interview series with designers, via mat3rial. MAT3RIAL: How did you become a graphic designer? JS: In high school, I fell in love with photography, and spent a large chunk of my time in the school darkroom, thanks to an incredibly supportive and encouraging art teacher. At the same time, I joined the Yearbook committee and started laying out pages, and designed covers for the school’s annual academic calendar. I still didn’t really know what a graphic designer was, and only discovered it as a profession once I started looking into post-secondary programs. It sounded like a fantastic way to have a career making work and being creative. It’s such a designer cliché, but I thought it was a more practical alternative to being a fine artist. MAT3RIAL: Who are the people who have influenced your aesthetics and your approach to design? JS: I graduated high school early so I could take a year off before heading to university, but at the last minute, my travel plans fell through. Well past the deadline to apply to most other institutions, (and in a bit of a panic), I applied to the Advertising program at the college in my hometown, and spent a year learning the basics of graphic arts: paste-up, presentation boards, crop marks and X-acto blades, copywriting, Quark Xpress, hand-rendering type, and rubber cement. At the time it all seemed superfluous and outdated, but the hands-on skills have served as my base ever since (especially since during undergrad the focus was more on thinking and concept, than it was on trimming and presentation overlays). What was originally considered a mere time-filler ended up being one of the most influential moves of my career. I think it’s important to know where your craft comes from. Sure, nobody does paste-up anymore, but I think it’s good to know how things used to be, to better understand how we got to where we are today. Letterpress printing is also an excellent history lesson. Personally, I think it should be mandatory that all graphic artists and designers learn how to set something by hand, pull some prints, then sort all the type. Understanding the amount of work that people used to do is kind of mind-boggling. Plus, all designers should know why it’s called ‘leading.’ During my undergrad at OCAD, I had an instructor who really taught outside the box and pushed the students creatively. He challenged me to think conceptually about things, and broadened my perspective on what design could be, blurring the lines between graphic and fine art. I learned what kind of designer I wanted to be in his class, and feel certain that my work would be very different today had I not been exposed to that kind of process and concept-driven practice early on. MAT3RIAL: Describe your creative process. JS: I do a lot of sketching, mostly with words instead of pictures. I try to always have some kind of conceptual grounding, through format, materials, visuals, etc. It’s important to me that decisions aren’t arbitrary, but based on some form of creative logic. Format and production methods are critical to figure out from the get-go for me and inform much of the design that follows, but can easily bog me down if I’m not careful. Once I have some ideas, I try to spit out as many iterations as I can, and then sift through things to find a couple strong concepts to push forward. I am a big fan of brainstorming with others, and have a select few people that know me well whom I trust to tell me when things aren’t working. MAT3RIAL: What has been your best project and why? JS: Certainly one of my favourite projects has been creating the promotional material for the OCAD U Sculpture/Installation Thesis Exhibitions. Since the parameters stay pretty much the same, one of the main challenges is to come up with something unique and engaging each year. It’s been an opportunity to try new production techniques and push formats, and over the years has given me the chance to work and experiment with many different printers – from screen-printing the material myself, to large-run trade printers, to smaller, independent printers producing really innovative results. This will be my tenth year working on it, so it acts as an interesting visual record of my work over the last decade. Two other projects that stand out for me are the albums I designed for my very talented musician/writer friend, Dinah Thorpe. She was open to almost anything, and pretty much gave me free rein, which was incredibly refreshing. I think the most recent album, Lullabies and Wake-up Calls is one of my most successful professional pieces. Both albums received JUNO nominations for Recording Package of the Year. MAT3RIAL: What is the most challenging part of graphic design work? JLS: Clients. Also, as a print designer, knowing that I’m part of an industry that creates a huge amount of waste, and kills a lot of trees. MAT3RIAL: I tell my students (at IIT) to think carefully about paper size to maximize the format depending on the printer they work with, and to also consider ink usage in this regard. Are there practices that a designer can have to make their practice more environmentally conscious? I always try to encourage my clients to print less. Why order 2000 copies, when you’ll only use 500? If format is open, I try to have a chat with the printer to figure out what size will have the least amount of wastage. I think it’s great that you tell your students the same – it seems this kind of information might be lacking in school. I also aim to use paper with high recycled content as much as possible. Dual purpose pieces (for example, a poster/invite combo) is also a small way of reducing.

item.title: Visualizing Bibliographic Metadata for Art Historical Research
item.dc:creator: MAT3RIALadmin
item.content:encoded: Over the past two years, Corina has been working with colleagues Tomasz Neugebauer (Digital Projects & Systems Development Librarian at Concordia University) and Felicity Tayler (PhD Candidate, Humanities Doctoral Program at Concordia University) on a data visualization project using the bibliographic metadata from the Artexte collection. Together they presented some of this work and their findings (and open questions) at the Art History Graduate Students Association Conference (AHGSA) in March 2015. Below is the abstract of the presentation: This paper responds to the crossover in conference topics between network science and art historical research methods. We ask how the visualization of complex networks can be used to generate art historical questions? Our data set is derived from the bibliographic database created by Artexte, an organization with the mandate to comprehensively collect Canadian exhibition catalogues and related international materials. The nodes of this network include the documents in the Artexte collections, connected to each other through edges representing subject cataloguing (keywords), and contributors, such as: artists, writers, editors, translators, critics, publishers, art organizations, etc. The resulting network of 40,000 e-artexte catalogue records contains over 135,000 nodes and more than 320,000 edges. The emerging research questions for this exploratory study include: (1) does the bibliographic metadata network exhibit the properties of complex networks (properties associated with small-world and scale-free networks) found in previous studies? (2) can the visualization of bibliographic metadata as a network contribute to art historical research? (3) is the measure of betweenness-centrality in the complex network derived from the e-artexte dataset useful to art historical research? We used measures of centrality to determine how important a particular node is to the entire structure. Although we initially thought these measures might reflect canonization processes, they seem to point to something else. Rather than mapping who has the most power in the art world because they are exhibited, published or written about most frequently, it seems to map which publications, writers, artists, curators are most important in holding the whole net together. What meaning does this outcome have for art historical methods?

item.title: Mining Immigrant Bodies
item.dc:creator: MAT3RIALadmin
item.content:encoded: A Multi-Ethnic Oral History of Industry, Environment, and Health in the Sudbury Region. Project developed in collaboration with Trina Daniel.
item.excerpt:encoded: A Multi-Ethnic Oral History of Industry, Environment, and Health in the Sudbury Region

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: A cross-cultural and intergenerational oral history project, Mining Immigrant Bodies focuses on the varied experiences of postwar immigrant miners and their families in the Sudbury region to understand the visible and invisible effects that pollutants have had on their bodies.
Stacey Zembrzycki, Oral History Center, Concordia University

item.title: Lost Stories
item.dc:creator: MAT3RIALadmin
item.excerpt:encoded: The Lost Stories Project seeks out little known stories about the Canadian past and transforms them into inexpensive, site-specific works of public art.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Ronald Rudin, Oral History Center, Concordia University

The Lost Stories Project seeks out little known stories about the Canadian past and transforms them into inexpensive, site-specific works of public art. This process is documented through a series of short films. Along the way, forgotten moments from Canadian history are brought to light, and viewers have an opportunity to see the choices that have to be made when a story is turned into a work of art.

item.title: The Directory of artist-run centres and collectives
item.dc:creator: MAT3RIALadmin
item.excerpt:encoded: The Directory is an online database of artist-run centres and collectives (ARCs) across Canada.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The Directory is an online database of artist-run centres and collectives (ARCs) across Canada. It allows artists, curators, administrators, and the general public to search artist-run centres using a variety of filters including association, location, type, discipline, and submission deadlines.

item.title: Making Makers received a GLAMi Nomination!
item.dc:creator: MAT3RIALadmin
item.content:encoded:
In the context of the Museums and the Web conference Making Makers, the project we developed with Michael Alstad for the Textile Museum of Canada, received a GLAMi Nomination (previously the Best of the Web Awards).

Museums and the Web is an annual conference featuring advanced research and exemplary applications of digital practice for cultural, natural and scientific heritage. Formed by leading professionals from around the world, our community has been meeting since 1997. The products of our meetings and conversations – the MW proceedings, Best of the Web archives and community news forum – are an unparalleled resource for museum workers, technologists, students and researchers that grows every year.
Read more about the nomination here.

item.title: Making Makers receives 2016 Media & Technology MUSE Award
item.dc:creator: MAT3RIALadmin
item.content:encoded: The Making Makers website, developed by MAT3RIAL in collaboration with Michael Alstad of Year Zero One, received a 2016 Media & Technology MUSE Award from the American Alliance of Museums. The site is produced by the Textile Museum of Canada with the support of the .CA Community Investment Program. The Textile Museum of Canada was presented with the MUSE Award in the category Digital Communities on Thursday, May 26, 2016 at the 2016 American Alliance of Museums Annual Meeting in Washington, DC. There to receive the award was the Museum’s Executive Director, Dr. Shauna McCabe. This award recognizes the Textile Museum of Canada’s high achievement in the application of media and technology to Gallery, Library, Archive, and Museum (GLAM) programs. See the press release.
